page.title: 05Ivy Farm
page.content: The farmhouse dates from 1607 and is built in traditioanl form of Long House. This means that the room lead from one into another to form a line. It was built using ships timbers as the frame, and small bricks with some stone at the base of the walls. The front of the house is timbered from about two metes from the ground up to the eaves. The back of the house is not timbered but the roof slopes down to a height of 1 metre from ground. The house was origially thatched,and this was replaced with tile roof in about 1900. It must be assumed that when first it was built there would be no upper storey. Not one of the four bedrooms has a vertical outer wall and their windows are all dormer.There are vertical timbers exposed on interior walls. One of the interior walls was constructed of wattle and daub.
